dict.string: Configures Jamf Connect Login configuration settings
Optional. A human-readable description of this payload. This description is shown on the Detail screen.
A unique identifier for the payload, dot-delimited. Usually root PayloadIdentifier+subidentifier
A reverse-DNS-style identifier for the specific payload. It is usually the same identifier as the root-level PayloadIdentifier value with an additional component appended.
The type of the payload, a reverse dns string.
A globally unique identifier for the payload. The actual content is unimportant, but it must be globally unique. In macOS, you can use uuidgen to generate reasonable UUIDs.
The version of the whole configuration profile.

The version number of the individual payload. A profile can consist of payloads with different version numbers. For example, changes to the VPN software in iOS might introduce a new payload version to support additional features, but Mail payload versions would not necessarily change in the same release.
This value describes the issuing organization of the profile, as displayed to the user
Specifies the IdP provider integrated with Jamf Connect Login. The following values may be used: Azure GoogleID IBMCI OneLogin.
Specifies the IdP provider integrated with Jamf Connect Login.
Redirect URI used by the native application in Azure
The Client ID of the added app in your IdP used to authenticate the user. This value should match the OIDCROPGID key.
The contents of a .jamfconnectlicense file encoded in Base64 data format.

Determines if users can bypass network authentication and use the Local Auth button at the loginwindow. If set to true, the Local Auth button is not available, and user must authenticate to their network.
If set to false, the Local Auth button is available, and users can choose to authenticate locally.
Determines if users can bypass network authentication and use the Local Auth button at the loginwindow.
Specifies which local users can still locally authorize if the DenyLocal key is set to true.

Allows local accounts to be migrated to network accounts. This is typically used when the user account was already created on the system, but you want the accounts to have the same username and password as the user’s Okta identity.

Jamf Connect Login does this by forcing the user to sign in with their IdP, and then attempts to match the user with an existing local account. Consider the following user migration scenarios:
If a user's network username and password match a local username and password, the account is considered migrated. No additional steps are needed. If a user's network username matches a local username but the passwords do not match, the user will be prompted to enter their current local password. Once successfully entered, Jamf Connect Login will use the current local password and the current network password to sync the account to the current network password. If a user's network username does not match any local account, the user will be given the option to create or migrate a local account. To migrate an account, the user must provide the existing local password. At this point Jamf Connect Login will synchronize the password to the network password, and then add the network username as an alias to the local account. This way the user can sign in to the system as their network username. Additionally, IdPs can migrate users from local accounts to accounts associated with network identity. With the Migrate and DenyLocal preference keys, all subsequent sign-ins will be authenticated to your IdP, and then the system verifies if the user record has an IdPUser attribute. If this attribute cannot be verified, the user will be asked to select a local account to associate with the user’s network account. If the local account shortname does not match the network shortname, the network name will be added as an alias to the account so the user will be able to use either one. This also keeps the home folder path and other elements of the user record the same.

Allows local accounts to be migrated to network accounts. This is typically used when the user account was already created on the system, but you want the accounts to have the same username and password as the user’s cloud identity.
Jamf Connect Login does this by forcing the user to sign in with their IdP, and then attempts to match the user with an existing local account. Consider the following user migration scenarios:
If a user's network username and password match a local username and password, the account is considered migrated. No additional steps are needed. If a user's network username matches a local username but the passwords do not match, the user will be prompted to enter their current local password. Once successfully entered, Jamf Connect Login will use the current local password and the current network password to sync the account to the current network password. If a user's network username does not match any local account, the user will be given the option to create or migrate a local account. To migrate an account, the user must provide the existing local password. At this point Jamf Connect Login will synchronize the password to the network password, and then add the network username as an alias to the local account. This way the user can sign in to the system as their network username. Additionally, IdPs can migrate users from local accounts to accounts associated with network identity. With the Migrate and DenyLocal preference keys, all subsequent sign-ins will be authenticated to your IdP, and then the system verifies if the user record has an IdPUser attribute. If this attribute cannot be verified, the user will be asked to select a local account to associate with the user’s network account. If the local account shortname does not match the network shortname, the network name will be added as an alias to the account so the user will be able to use either one. This also keeps the home folder path and other elements of the user record the same.
Note: For every successful network authentication of a user, the user’s record will be updated with the “NetworkSignIn” attribute. If the user was only authenticated locally, this attribute will not be updated.

For every successful network authentication of a user, the user’s record will be updated with the “NetworkSignIn” attribute. If the user was only authenticated locally, this attribute will not be updated.
Specifies which local accounts are excluded from the migration pull-down menu.

The Client ID of the added app in you IdP used for authenticating the user's password via a resource owner password grant (ROPG) workflow. This value should match the OIDCClientID key. Note: Google ID does not support ROPG workflows.
The Client ID of the added app in you IdP used for authenticating the user's password via a resource owner password grant (ROPG) workflow. This value should match the OIDCClientID key.

If set to true, the user must create a new password on the computer If set to false, the user must validate with their existing IdP password, which will also become the local password.
Important: If using Google ID as your IdP, this key must be set to true.
If set to true, the user must create a new password on the computer If set to false, the user must validate with their existing IdP password, which will also become the local password.
If using Google ID as your IdP, this key must be set to true.
Determines which roles become an admin at the loginwindow. Users assigned a specified role become an admin at the loginwindow. You can also specify an array of strings to list multiple users
Determines which roles become an admin at the loginwindow. Users assigned a specified role become an admin at the loginwindow.
The attribute in the user's SAML ID token used to determine if they are an admin user or not.
The client secret used by Jamf Connect Login and your IdP. Important: If using Google ID or OneLogin as your IdP, this key must be specified.
The client secret used by Jamf Connect Login and your IdP.
Specifies the IdP Tenant to use for authentication.
Ignores any cookies stored by the loginwindow.
When using the AuthUI rule, determines if the token cache is set to /tmp/cachedata.
Path to a locally stored image file used for the logo during password validation or local password creation.
Path to an image to use for the background of the login screen.
Text displayed when a user must enter a one time password (OTP).
URL to show at the loginwindow to allow for onboarding or Okta enrollment.
Path to an image used as a clickable logo for the Help URL at the loginwindow.
A path to a local file that users can access by clicking the "Help" button in the Jamf Connect Login window Note: Supported file types include PDF and HTML.
A path to a local file that users can access by clicking the "Help" button in the Jamf Connect Login window.
Supported file types include PDF and HTML.
Text used for the EULA. (Use three asterisks to create a line break in the text.)
You must include the JamfConnectLogin:EULA mechanism (which you can do with authchanger) to display the contents of EULAText.
Specifies the path to a folder where the end user's license agreement record (EULA) is stored.
Specifies the path to where the end user's license agreement record (EULA) is stored.
The user _securityagent must have write access to this folder.
If set to true, all users become local admins when created on the computer.
Determines if FileVault is enabled for the first user to sign in.
If set to true, Jamf Connect will store the FileVault recovery key to /var/db/NoMADFDE unless otherwise specified.
Specifies a custom path for the Recovery Key.
Specifies the path to the script or other executable run by the RunScript mechanism.
The arguments used with a specified script run by the RunScript mechanism Note: The ScriptPath key must bey specified.
The arguments used with a specified script run by the RunScript mechanism
Determines if mobile accounts should be demobilized.
